They face real difficulties as they attempt to stretch every last dollar in order for those in need to receive the same services granted to their counterparts in the city. Called upon to travel throughout the Huon and Kingborough municipalities, often in appalling weather conditions and at all hours of the day and night, these members of the palliative care community team, under the direction of Sally Williams, work miracles for the families and friends of those in need. I well remember the magnificent team who spent countless hours caring for the late Ben Jackson so that he could die with dignity in his home in Huonville: Betty Johns, Jane Jupp, Robyn Tollard, Liz, Linda and Patti. Seeing their commitment at first-hand confirmed my long-held belief that these workers are the forgotten operators in our health system.

I implore the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) to sit down with his state colleagues to ensure that realistic and adequate funding for this particular health area is settled as a matter of the highest priority. To continue to posture is not good enough. Dying patients and their families deserve far better.

talk.start.para: —Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is therefore adjourned and will be made an order of the day for the next sitting.

—Today I seek to highlight the government's gross mishandling of the end of war list for Vietnam, which has caused considerable dismay and anger in the veteran community. It continues a pattern already set by the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel (Mrs Bishop) with the so-called `double medalling' fiasco for Korean War veterans and her attempt to mislead naval veterans of the Malayan Emergency about the contents of a 1996 letter from the UK's First Sea Lord of the Admiralty.

speech.para: The issue has a long and fairly complex history. It arises because of a quota system in place during the war which restricted the number of medals and commendations that could be issued by commanding officers. This quota disadvantaged 78 ADF personnel, 28 of whom were given a lesser award than recommended by their commanding officer and another 50 who missed out completely at the time.

The end of war list is designed to correct this situation. It includes 59 veterans who were nominated for acts of gallantry and a further 19 nominated for meritorious service. It is the government's handling of the gallantry cases that is the point of contention and that has been indisputably inept. The complication arises because the veterans concerned were originally recommended for imperial medals, such as the Military Cross for officers or the Military Medal for other ranks. Australia is no longer able to award imperial honours. The replacement Australian system of honours is now fully operative and, under this system, the relevant level 3 medal is the Medal for Gallantry.

To everyone except the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel it would appear a relatively straightforward matter to award the veterans concerned the Medal for Gallantry in lieu of the imperial medals they were originally recommended for. It appears that the minister is happy to award the Medal for Gallantry to veterans who were recommended for the Military Cross but not to those who were recommended for the Military Medal. She has argued that the order of precedence requires her to award the latter veterans a commendation rather than the Medal for Gallantry. She clearly finds it difficult to explain why this is so. No-one else in the government or the veteran community seems keen to associate themselves with her position.

The opposition has been contacted by a number of experts on military medals who dispute the minister's contentions. They say that there is nothing in the order of precedence that requires the government to downgrade a recommendation for an imperial Military Medal to an Australian commendation. They say the Military Medal is a level 3 award but the commendation is a lesser, level 4 award. The key to the whole saga appears to be that the six or so veterans who were recommended for the Military Medal were not officers. The minister appears unhappy about awarding diggers the same gallantry medals as officers, so she has arbitrarily downgraded gallantry by diggers to a commendation. In so doing she has undermined the very basis of the Australian system of honours, which was critically designed to move away from awards that were linked to rank or to service in a particular stream of the defence forces. She seeks to do something that the British Tory government long ago repudiated and got rid of.

Despite her denial on radio 2GB on 18 March, it remains the case that only officers are to get gallantry medals under the end of war list. While some ordinary diggers are to get medals for meritorious service, none are to receive medals for gallantry. This is what the debate is about and her comments, on that occasion, were designed to confuse the issue. During the same interview the minister implied that her critics were seeking to elevate diggers' awards to give them higher recommendation than their commanding officers had recommended. This is totally false. The opposition and prominent veteran leaders like Bruce Ruxton are simply demanding that diggers get a medal, not a commendation, where this is what their commanding officer initially recommended.

The case of John Burridge, a Perth veteran and medals expert, highlights the incompetence shown in this matter. It is a bitter irony that he first went to Vietnam in 1968 as a 21-year-old national serviceman who was conscripted there by the coalition. He was recommended for the imperial Military Medal for acts of gallantry on 8 May 1969. The citation by his commanding officer, Lieutenant Colonel Khan, included the following passage:

Private Burridge moved forward, on his own initiative, to a position 15 metres from the enemy and commenced engaging the (enemy) bunkers. He maintained his position for over an hour and effectively prevented the enemy from moving to other bunkers on the flanks of the platoon. His actions drew most of the enemy rocket fire onto his position and as a result he was wounded in both legs. Despite his wounds and further enemy engagement of his position, Private Burridge continued to fire on the bunkers and restrict the effectiveness of the enemy fire until the remainder of the platoon could move to new positions. His courage and his complete disregard for his own safety were major factors in preventing further casualties to the platoon and his conduct was an inspiration to all.

Because of the quota system, John Burridge did not get the Military Medal he was recommended for. The relevant paperwork confirms that Lieutenant Colonel Khan's superiors, including the commander of Australian forces in Vietnam, Major General Hay, supported his recommendation. Solely because of the quota system, the only recognition that John Burridge received at the time was to be mentioned in dispatches in 1971. Because the imperial Military Medal cannot be awarded to him in 1998, he should get the Medal for Gallantry. He is instead being offered a commendation, which he describes as an insult and which he intends to reject.

Clearly the minister is seeking to alter what commanding officers in the field, with more experience and more knowledge than she has, actually recommended. The government seems more interested in the fact that Mr Burridge was a private, and a conscript to boot, than in his bravery. To offer him a commendation on the basis of his rank is to compound the unfairness he suffered 29 years ago because of the quota system.

This unfairness has prompted the RSL's Bruce Ruxton to go in to bat for these veterans and to meet with the minister. By all accounts their meeting last week was a robust affair. Afterwards Mr Ruxton was quoted in the Canberra Times on 18 March as saying:

We'll keep on punching, we'll keep up the pressure because it's crazy. . . It's not right because they are awarding one thing to officers and another to other ranks. . . (Veterans) are furious; it's just another knock for the Vietnam vets.
A letter to the editor in the Age of 5 March from Bruce Sim of Sunbury reinforces these criticisms. He wrote:

For 26 years, Vietnam veterans have waited for their comrades to receive their nation's honour for acts of unstinting heroism. Our current Government was elected with a promise to finalise the End of War list. Details of the list have recently been published but once again Vietnam veterans have been slapped in the face and treated with contempt. The End of War list will award gallantry medals to officers, and other ranks will receive commendations . . . This is nonsense and, to the shame of this nation, it continues what is becoming a tradition of kicking in the teeth those who served their country.

The minister should have the good grace to reconsider her decision and provide a gallantry medal to those who have more than earned such recognition. Quite clearly this latest situation is one in which she finds very few supporters in the veteran community, very few supporters amongst the people who participated in the war in Vietnam, very few supporters amongst the officers who made the recommendations and very few supporters, quite frankly, in the government of this country.

In the brief moments left to me I would like to turn to another matter. I congratulate the alliance of councils in western Sydney for their efforts today in lobbying the government over the question of Badgerys Creek. They are the representatives of 1½ million Australians who are increasingly concerned with the flaws in the EIS. In this flawed EIS we are seeing a situation where those carrying out the purported survey are ensuring that there is minimal public right to participate. The recent announcement that form letters will basically be ignored typifies the attempt to try to enforce—

talk.start.para: —Hear, hear!

—`Hear, hear,' the member for North Sydney says. He defends a practice in which this EIS is seeking to minimise public participation, seeking to minimise the rights of constituents in western Sydney to have a say in this process. I congratulate those councils regardless of their political affiliations for the way they have taken up this campaign against an airport which promises western Sydney and 1½ million Australians 70,000 extra vehicle trips a day, increased pollution and the aggravation of learning difficulties. I commend those councils' activities. The government must consider very seriously the Snowy Mountains organisation's analysis and criticism of this EIS.

—I would like to comment on the disadvantages experienced by women in the modern Australian work force. Unfortunately, for many women there is a choice: career or family. While choosing to raise a family should never, ever be belittled, women who wish to pursue a career must, as Janet Davison Rowley so poignantly said:

speech.para: Choose to have a career early and a family late or choose . . . to have a family early and a career late.
Ms Rowley added that if women choose a family followed by a career then:
. . . the careerist woman must plan for a long life.

Despite a significant increase in the number of women entering the work force, women's work force participation in full-time employment is still substantially lower than that of men, particularly for married women with children.

In February 1997 nearly 57 per cent of men, 44 per cent of women and 26 per cent of married women were employed. Of these, approximately 67 per cent of men, 33 per cent of women and only 19 per cent of married women were in full-time employment. The most significant figures for the same period relate to part-time employment. Only 25 per cent of men were engaged in part-time employment, while 75 per cent of women and 48 per cent of married women held part-time positions. This defies growing work force trends, for example, in the United States, where increasingly men are taking more than one part-time job to compensate for the structural changes in full-time employment.

There are, however, significant disadvantages to women in part-time employment. There is usually limited access to training, career development and superannuation, and hanging over all part-time workers is a general feeling of questionable job security. This is so particularly because of the inevitable restructuring in the work force due to technological advances and the impact of social and economic factors. Despite these drawbacks, the Work and Family—Achieving Integration study in 1994 found that 75 per cent of women with children preferred to be in the labour force, mainly in part-time work.

Over the last decade there has been a discernible trend towards female-friendly work environments. This has allowed inroads to be made, particularly in management roles but not in the less skilled roles characterised by low pay, casual or part-time hours and poor training. Large Australian companies such as Lend Lease Corporation have established consultative bodies to look at ways to help employees manage work and family issues. Westpac Banking Corporation is another Australian company seeking to improve part-time career prospects for employees by examining ways to create a more family-friendly work environment. In addition, enterprise bargaining could provide an opportunity to redress work place inequalities for women. And these are the same enterprise bargaining opportunities that the Labor Party has so vehemently opposed over the last four to five years and continues to oppose at every available opportunity.

However, it is an inescapable fact that working mothers consistently report difficulties in managing work and child-care responsibilities, and full-time working hours are on the increase because women are finding it increasingly difficult to dictate their working hours. Above this, women are making a huge contribution to the volunteer sector, and in many instances these women are not just full-time mums. The 1991 study Juggling time undertaken by the Office of the Status of Women revealed that women perform about 70 per cent of unpaid work, which equates to 3.39 billion hours per annum. When it is noted that women also perform 3.56 billion hours per year of paid work it is obvious that many women work a double shift of paid work followed by unpaid work. I can particularly attest to this in relation to Meals on Wheels and other community service activities that occur in my electorate, where many women are making sacrifices beyond their normal day-to-day hourly paid work.

In the view of some, the two-income household of the 1990s has allowed women to, supposedly, have it all. It has given them the opportunity to take advantage of the structural community advances of the last two decades, including opportunities for further education and entry to professional employment. However, this change has not engendered a realignment of the division of labour in the home. For far too long the division of labour in the home has been seen as inherently genetic: a trait to which men are not privy. But it is obvious that the influx of women into the ranks of the employed and their desire to stay there after the birth of their children necessitates a re-division of household labour, and this labour includes the rearing of children.

I am particularly pleased that the member for Dawson (Mrs De-Anne Kelly) is beside me as I give this speech because she is a very good example of someone who has a very promising career and at the same time has to balance it with the obligations of being a full-time mum.

It is not insignificant that for a male employee a family indicates stability and maturity, whilst for a female employee a family assumes the role of a liability. Not surprisingly, in this double-standard laden environment most female employees agonise over the decision of when to start a family. The spectre of increasing numbers of female workers has not brought about a change in the traditional employment mores, which clearly favour the interests of males in the workplace. Although the presence of females in the workplace is obviously the norm, more is required from men than a general `welcome to the fold' before the concept of a working mother becomes a viable reality for women.

It is indisputable that working women need to have access to adequate child-care facilities. It has not gone unnoticed that this federal parliament of Australia is failing to lead by example when it comes to supplying adequate child-care facilities—and I say that as someone who at the moment does not have any children. Heaven help the young mothers or, for that matter, the young fathers, such as Senator Winston Crane, seeking a parliamentary career, whether as a member or a senator, or even as a staffer.

We need to give women in the workplace real options when it comes to working and motherhood. The option of giving up paid work altogether contrasts starkly with the vision held by many women of their own future—women who have gone on to further their education, who have sought to fulfil their ambition and gain financial independence along the way. And despite the easing of child-care problems which working from home has to offer, it is an inescapable fact that women workers also enjoy the camaraderie of the office workplace and benefit from the social contact, just as men do.

The Department of Management at the University of Melbourne has reasoned that failing to introduce family friendly workplaces can cost employers almost $75,000 every time a key employee resigns. Facing a high turnover like this, employers clearly need to find a balance that will accommodate flexible working hours, parental leave and assistance with child care.

Women are leaving full-time work in their droves for reasons not totally attributable to wanting more time with their children; nor is it because they hate work. It is because working women are finding it increasingly more difficult to keep up their dream of the perfect scenario: wife, mother and careerist. The juggling act has become too difficult, and working women are resigning in the face of work practices which accommodate careerist husbands and fathers but fail to accommodate the long-term benefits that changing the rules to accommodate working women would bring.

It is therefore imperative that this brain drain be stemmed—for not only does the flow of women from the work force equate to a very real reduction in profitability and impact negatively on the level of competitiveness, but also society at large will suffer from the loss of initiative and prowess that these women take with them when they exit the work force. As legislators and members of this House, we should not always be forced to respond to socioeconomic inadequacies such as those borne by career women by imposing punitive measures on business. However, as a member of this House, I am going to do all I can to ensure that the choice faced by Janet Davison Rowley is little more than an historical hiccup on the road for true equality in the workplace.

talk.start.para: —I grieve today for industrial relations in Australia. Over the past two years the trade union movement, its members and supporters have been under sustained and unprecedented daily pressure, attack, ridicule and abuse by members of the Howard government—and no-one has played a more divisive and destructive role than the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business (Mr Reith).

speech.para: Last week, in an extraordinary admission, the minister actually confirmed that he had provided personal advice to the management of Patrick stevedores that they should not pay their work force because of a ban placed on overtime. The minister has totally overstepped his responsibilities as a minister of the Crown. Instead of trying to calm and defuse industrial disputes, and encourage resolution of disputes by negotiation in good faith, he is acting like an industrial relations consultant, pushing the line of the boss, at the expense of the workers.

This is a minister who is prepared to pour petrol on any industrial spot fire to ensure that it flares into a major bushfire. Deliberate provocation is the essential ingredient of industrial relations under this minister. This action of deliberately provoking industrial disputes then stepping in with draconian measures is a very old ploy in industrial relations.

What is most galling about the minister's personal advice to Patrick management is the fact that he and his colleagues, like the honourable member for Gilmore (Mrs Gash), run around the place every day, abusing waterfront workers and accusing them of engaging in a rort by using overtime to bolster their wages. Last week, on ABC Radio Wollongong, the member for Gilmore made outrageous comments about wages and conditions of waterside workers. I doubt that she has ever been on the waterfront; most certainly she has never been on the waterfront at Port Kembla.

When waterfront workers place a ban on overtime, government members run around the place with indignation, screaming blue murder; they then advise the boss that the workers should receive no pay at all for the work performed. On the AM program on Friday, 20 March 1998, the minister said:

. . . the Government condemns this strike. It is not in the national interest; it's not in the interests of the members themselves . . . I call on the MUA to call off this strike . . . This is a campaign of vengeance and greed.

Vengeance is a feature of the involvement of the minister who stirs for conflict. Who was stirring for conflict in Cairns last year? Who was involved in the Dubai debacle? Who has been involved up to his neck in the Webb Dock lease to the NFF?

The Howard government has played a serious and crucial role in all of these industrial conflicts—and, in time, all of the involvement will be revealed. I have never been able to understand the hatred this government has for the union movement and its members, especially those of the Maritime Union of Australia and the miners federation. I have no fundamental disagreement with workers choosing whether or not to be members of a union. All workers should have the right to make this decision. But also fundamental to this decision is whether or not a worker who chooses not to join a union should accept the flow-on of benefits gained by unions and their members through improved wages and conditions.

It is very disappointing to see workers who choose not to be members of a union taking the benefit of a flow-on from negotiations by a union and the employer or through industrial actions. It is their right, they argue, not to be a member of a union, but they seem to me to be something like a parasite when they take the benefits that are gained. Too many of the workers who choose not to join a union happen to be only too prepared to take the increase in wages and better conditions which are won by unionists in the same workplace or industry.

Workers have a right, as I said, to join a union if they choose. It is a right no-one can dispute but, equally, the increases in wages and better conditions which flow from the actions of a union and its members should not be available to those workers who make that choice. Workers who are not members of a union should not, as a matter of principle, accept the hard-won gains obtained by unions.

I have always said that no worker knows the value of a trade union until they find they require its services. I have lost count of how many times a worker has been to my office, contacted me by phone or even written to me legitimately concerned about not being paid or not receiving some proper entitlement for their work. My first question always is, `What does your union say?' All too often they say that they are not in a union. It frustrates me no end to hear this response from workers who will not join a union, yet when they are in trouble—because they are being short-changed, are not receiving their normal hours, are being sacked or because the firm that employs them has gone broke—they run back into the fold of the union movement.

I have had many cases of this over the last couple of weeks. I had one case over the Christmas break of about 20 teenagers who were employed at Shellharbour Square which became known as `the trolleyboys dispute'. This young group of teenagers wanted to get some money over the Christmas holiday for various purposes—one wanted to buy a pushbike and other things—and they got a job collecting trolleys. An operator from Sydney came down to the Illawarra and undercut the local contractor. These lads were paid $6 an hour. The contractor from Sydney said to Shellharbour Square that he would do it for $600 a week cheaper. So he did it for $600 cheaper by cutting the lads' salary from $6 to the princely sum of $5 an hour.

But there was a catch to it: he said they all had to be retrained. The boys were retrained for two days on no pay at all. The contractor said the tractor drivers, who were a little bit older—I think they had to be 20 before they could drive a tractor—also had to be retrained. He chose their retraining day as New Year's Eve. It being a supermarket, one tractor driver worked on New Year's Eve for 13 hours and the new contractor told him that, as this was his training day, he would get no pay at all for the hours he had put in. The other boys—every one of them had been doing these jobs for a couple of weeks—were all retrained on one of those days over Christmas. The trolleyboys were retrained for two days, which meant they were not being paid at all for two days out of the princely sum that they were being paid.

Just after New Year's Day they turned up for work one night and they were told that they did not have a job. The employer just sacked the lot of them without bothering to pay them the sum of money that was owed. Some of their parents came to see me about it. I got involved and after many arguments and battles we eventually got the money back. Mind you, we had to threaten that Shellharbour Square would be closed to all business unless the boys' just entitlements were met. They were met. That contractor is no longer employed, I am pleased to say, by Shellharbour Square. I must say that I have no criticism of the management of Shellharbour Square. They always acted most honourably in regard to the trolleyboys. Mind you, the threat of having the whole supermarket complex closed and a picket line put around it helped them to act honourably. Nevertheless, I have no criticism at all about what they did.

Another case that I have recently been involved with concerns Pivot Fertilisers, a group in my area of Port Kembla which had four or six people working there for a couple of years. On Friday, 30 January these workers turned up for work and were told that the job that they had been doing for the past two years no longer existed. It is interesting to note that the company which provided the replacement workers is none other than the infamous Drake International, which has been granted an enormous slice of the employment services market by this government. No wonder those on the other side support them!

All too often today this sort of thing is happening in industrial relations: many workers' conditions have gone and when they have a legitimate complaint they find the avenues of complaint have been taken away. It is indeed a very rough time for industrial relations. I am very concerned about what the future holds for industrial relations in this country as I see hard-won conditions in the workplace continuing to be eroded.

talk.start.para: —I rise tonight to pay tribute to the Queensland Sugar Corporation and to congratulate the chairman of its board, Bruce Vaughan, and its chief executive officer, David Rutledge, and his team. Despite the recent downturn due to the Asian economic crisis in the market for raw sugar, they have effectively insulated Australia and its raw sugar exports from a downturn in pricing. In fact, the pool price for 1998 is anticipated to be higher than that for 1997. This has been done at a very difficult time for Australian industry, and I would like to share with the House the way in which our excellent Queensland Sugar Corporation has managed to achieve this very secure outcome for farmers, millers and others who derive a livelihood from our great sugar industry.

speech.para: I would like to dwell on the Asian economic crisis and the impact that it has had on the market for raw sugar. The result has been a collapse in the purchasing power of our South-East Asian neighbours. The Indonesian rupiah has fallen by 70 per cent of its value since mid 1997. The Korean won has fallen by 50 per cent. The reason for this is a large undisclosed corporate debt in US dollars which was unknown to regulators in that country. The reaction of consumers, certainly in the short term, has been panic buying.

As we know, the causes of the Asian crisis are that the Asian currencies have been artificially pegged high against the US dollar; there has been a great deal of encouragement for overseas borrowing; and US loans. The currency was devalued, so the ability to repay those loans has virtually evaporated. This has had an impact on the Australian raw sugar industry because Indonesia is a very large consumer of our sugar. Equally, Malaysia takes a good deal of Australian raw sugar. The market share within Malaysia is 70 per cent to 80 per cent Australian. We have exported to Malaysia 700,000 tonnes per year.

Regrettably, these countries do not have the purchasing power that they have had in the past. The effect of this is a decline in sugar consumption in the long term and demand globally. Previous to the crisis in South-East Asia, it appeared that supply and demand were pretty much in balance. However, it now appears likely that there is going to be a surplus of raw sugar internationally. Since January, there has been a substantial fall in price. Last year, the price for raw sugar worldwide was 12c per pound US. Since 29 December, we have experienced a price fall of between 15 per cent and 20 per cent.

I am pleased to say that the Queensland Sugar Corporation, the single desk seller for Queensland sugar, had the foresight to take out a great deal of price cover. The proportion of the 1998 crop which was priced at the beginning of February 1998 was 60 per cent—an unparalleled amount of raw sugar to be priced and forward sold. The hedging strategies have insulated the industry for 1998. As I have said, it is anticipated that the pool price in 1998 will be even better than it was in 1997.

This is in no small part due to the relationship with refiners in South-East Asian countries. Queensland Sugar Corporation has taken great care to build strong business relationships with many of the refiners throughout South-East Asia. This good working relationship and trust has left our industry largely unaffected, certainly for 1998.

I would like to turn to what it means for Australia as a whole that the Queensland Sugar Corporation has had the foresight to sell 60 per cent of Australia's sugar in February of this year. The anticipated revenue for 1998 for our nation is $2 billion. You would be aware that every one cent per pound movement in the sugar price means that Australia loses $170 million—if that movement is down, of course—or $33 per tonne. Also, every cent of movement in the exchange rate means a loss to Australia of $25 million, or $5 a tonne. If we had had a situation where we did not have a single desk seller with the foresight to hedge, the drop in revenue for our country would have been $200 million. Furthermore, if we had a situation where we had not had a single desk seller and our mills had been scrambling, one against the other, to undercut and to sell at what was obviously a rapidly dropping price for raw sugar worldwide, we would have dropped a further $80 million from our exports.

Because of the foresight of the Queensland Sugar Corporation, this country has had a further $280 million worth of exports that it would not have had if, one, there had not been forward selling and hedging and, two, if there had not been a single desk seller. I would like to congratulate the Queensland Sugar Corporation. However, not everybody is as generous.

I turn now to a presentation by Graeme Samuel, the President of the National Competition Council, which was made to the New Market Culture Conference in February 1998—the very time that the Queensland Sugar Corporation was so wisely insulating us against a fall in the raw sugar price. The National Competition Council has a number of responsibilities, but I will dwell on only one. It assesses the performance of various jurisdictions in meeting their national competition policy commitments. It also advises the Treasurer on whether the states and territories have achieved enough to justify their share of $16 billion of national competition payments.

There is a saying that you can tell a technocrat but you cannot tell him much. I am afraid that Mr Samuel fits into this category. He said that there were some questionable arguments used to support the retention of the domestic marketing monopoly and single desk export sales in 1996 for the sugar industry regulation. What he said was really quite extraordinary. He said that the alternative to single desk selling is—wait for it—voluntary cooperative arrangements.

This is extraordinarily naive. We do not have voluntary cooperative arrangements in the coal industry, and we have seen a recent plummet, regrettably for Australia, in coal prices. We do not see voluntary cooperative arrangements such that we do not need referees and coaches in sport. We do not see voluntary cooperative arrangements between motorists such that we do not need traffic police. I have to say that the thought that an export industry would voluntarily cooperate is quite naive.

We have a mandatory single desk seller which is extraordinarily successful. We have just seen $280 million being added to Australia's exports for 1998 in what has been one of the most severe downturns we have experienced with our exports. Mr Samuel has taken very much a technocratic view of this and has not looked at the very fine way in which the Queensland Sugar Corporation operates.

I would just make one final comment. Mr Samuel has made the point that, for the purposes of assessing compliance with the national competition policy agreements, the council takes the agreements as binding not only on the jurisdiction's government but also its parliament, particularly as governments change over time. We therefore expect the government to ensure that the parliament passes all appropriate reforms. Mr Deputy Speaker, like your good self, I swore an oath of allegiance to our sovereign, to God and most particularly to the people of my constituency. I am afraid I do not swear an oath of allegiance to the National Competition Council, and I think that Mr Samuel should really address his concerns in a far more thoughtful manner. I would like to congratulate again the Queensland Sugar Corporation and draw to the attention of farmers and millers throughout Australia the fine job they have done and will continue to do. They can be guaranteed the support of the Queensland National Party and of our members Australia wide in their excellent work.

talk.start.para: —On 18 March 1998, just around the corner from my electorate office, I attended a rally organised by teachers and students of the Adult Migrant English Service in my electorate of Blaxland. That service has provided English language teaching to humanitarian cases and refugees and new migrant entrants to Australia for the past 26 years in my electorate. In fact, the organisation has been running for 50 years in the state of New South Wales. The rally was organised to protest against the tendering process that had been put in place by the current Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, the Hon. Philip Ruddock. In that tendering process, which the Education Union and the AMES teachers argued had been faulty, was virtually all of the provision of English language teaching to newly arrived migrants. Each migrant is capable of getting 510 hours teaching to enable them to be able to cope adequately with living in this new society they are in and to provide a sound basis for them to become a complete part of the community, to seek work within that community and support their families.

speech.para: On 18 March various people attended and spoke: teachers, members of the community, members of groups, students and I. We did not have the minister present and we did not have any official delegate of the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs present. Instead, we had two members of the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs there, but they were not allowed to say what their name was; they were there purely to take notes. The next day the minister was at the National Press Club and gave a speech entitled `Immigration reform: the unfinished agenda'. He outlined a series of things I will go to shortly, and in particular one charge that is extremely vicious in relation to the Australian Labor Party and in relation to the former ministers for immigration during the 13 years of the Hawke and Keating governments.

There was no response by the minister to the 500 AMES teachers in New South Wales who from I July will be without a job in the area of their expertise, teaching English to newly arrived migrants. All of those people will have been displaced as of 1 July this year. When the minister went to the Press Club, he also issued a media release. There was no response to the people at the rally; that came the next day. The next day he announced that the first contract had been signed for English language tuition in New South Wales. He was very proud of that. He said in the press release:

The contract between the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs and a consortium led by the Australian Centre for Languages, ACL, is the first to be awarded in New South Wales under the open tendering process.

The very first one in New South Wales, announced on 19 March, the day after that rally, was the excision of Adult Migrant English Service teachers from their role as of 1 July, after 26 very proud years of intensive effort and high quality professional expertise rendered in the service of their students. But Mr Ruddock in this press release effectively denies their competence, denies their professional expertise and denies the manner in which they taught for all of those 26 years in Bankstown and the 50 years that that organisation has taught in New South Wales. He states this:

The new service delivery arrangements will provide better services for clients including a wider choice of provider, more flexibility in service delivery options, and better pathways to further study or employment.

None of the students who were at the rally could bring themselves at this point in time to expect that they will have those advantages out of these new tendering processes, and certainly none of those experienced teachers expect this to be the outcome either.

He argued that the aim in moving to open tendering was to improve the flexibility and effectiveness of English language tuition, while ensuring best value for money. That is the key here, not all the rest: the fact that the lowest tenderer at the lowest cost ended up with the contracts. We have already seen lots of other examples from the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Dr Kemp, in terms of providing tender processes and people getting in because they are providing the lowest cost service—not the best but the lowest cost. He also argued that there were advances in technology that help providers deliver English language services that are responsive to the changing needs of clients. I can only think that he is talking about the computer program, developed at a cost of millions of dollars by his department, that those AMES teachers have been using; that those services and computer resources will be given to the Australian Centre for Languages for them to use for the students that were previously taught by AMES teachers. So he argues that there will be an ongoing improvement in the way in which they are taught.

Not one person at that rally believes what is in the press release of 19 March from the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs. They know that there was a real quality program based on the professionalism of those AMES teachers and they know that this tender process, having been brought to a conclusion early, is the only answer that they are going to get from this minister. So in my electorate those people have been greatly hampered.

I want to touch on one thing that he dealt with in relation to immigration reform and the unfinished agenda at the press conference. He spoke about the inheritance that he received as a result of Labor being in government. He said:
In essence, the Australian Labor Party in Government was almost single-handedly responsible for destroying the Australian community's confidence in immigration policies and programs;

I find that utterly offensive, as someone who worked for the previous Treasurer and Prime Minister and as someone who spent 10 years involved in ensuring that we had the best quality immigration program with the strongest possible controls. I, as the person in that position, regard that statement as utterly offensive. I am sure that every minister for immigration who gave their best efforts to ensure that our borders were secure and that the program was full, fair and equitable would share those sentiments. He went on to say:
- Australians no longer saw them as operating in the national interest;
- in many ways, these policies and programs provided fertile ground for the emergence of intolerance and in some cases outright racism.

Here is the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs accusing the previous government of engendering racism in the community as a result of its immigration policies. Since this government came to power that message has been on their agenda. There was that message in the election campaign prior to March 1996, and that message has been in their kit ever since that election.

We have a minister now who has openly said that racism in relation to the immigration program is a result of the previous Labor government. That is utterly offensive to anyone who has been involved in ensuring that we had a good, strong, fair immigration system. If there was only one thing that we did wrong while in government, as I pointed out in May last year, was not to tell all of the Australian people as forcefully as we could just how strong an immigration program we had.

But, in league with the member for Bennelong, the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs has utterly distorted the situation that existed before he came to power as the minister. He full well knows how strong our immigration system was. This attack is a political one in preparation for the next election. Tied with the question of Aboriginal rights and the Wik debate, this is another of the underlying themes this coalition government will take to the next election—with social security matters being another one. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I was going to talk today about a very important issue that a number of our colleagues in this place would have presented to them almost daily—and that is the issue of the Child Support Agency. Case after case is presented to me which indicate that there are major problems associated with the Child Support Agency, and it is an issue we must address. Two parliamentary reports have done nothing to change it. We are changing things slightly. But I also think there is a greater need associated with the Family Law Act, which is the basis of the CSA's problems, and it needs fixing.

speech.para: But there is a greater concern. I grieve today for my country and my community in relation to one specific issue. Over the last 12 months or so we have had a lot of people in the Australian community declaring themselves as weeping for their country, feeling dread for their country and feeling sorry that certain things do not happen in their country. There has been hand wringing about certain issues over certain disadvantaged groups. Frankly, they have been supported by a number of members in this place on both sides of the House.

I have checked the Hansard since 1995. Except for a handful of my colleagues in this particular place, not much mention has been made, of any substance—and I apologise to anyone if it this is not the case—concerning disability services. There is a severe problem associated with disability services in the community.
I am thankful to Father John Jegorow in the gallery who has said:
The say the test of any civilised country is the manner in which they treat their helpless.

Disabled people cannot care for themselves. Their needs are present for every moment, every day, every week, every month, every year. They cannot care for themselves. They are excluded from opportunity within our community. Their parents are faced with an unremitting battle where they have to plead and beg for help not only within the community but also for funding and during the whole process. There is a daily dread within families with disabled people of breaking down within their family.

So I grieve today for the attitude, the approach and the lack of action that all governments in this country and all communities have towards disability services. Let me preface these comments. I am not pointing the finger at this government, the last government, the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), the Treasurer (Mr Costello) or the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) because I believe those three members are as compassionate as anyone else that I have met in this place. The problem that we have is the system in which we fund community services specifically with disability services. The problem lies not with politicians but with the bean counters.

At the moment 13,400 people within our community require funding, 1,500 of which have profound disabilities and need help, need funding, but we are not adequately meeting these funding needs. Some 8,000 parents—that is, families—who are over 65 are still caring for their disabled children. These parents find it very difficult to cope with the lives they have with their children. I will quote from a newsletter I have here from the time to care program. It says:
If I was to die tomorrow or become ill and unable to care for Matt temporarily or permanently, could you please tell me where Matt would go?
This is from Grace P., who is a sole carer. Another quote from Mrs D.W.:
First of all, having a handicapped child brings with it a tremendous responsibility, which can be very hard on relationships—that is why my husband and I divorced.
Another person, Ms V., said:

When cuts are made to disability funding, the reality of it is that families have to play an even greater role and take on yet more responsibilities. From somewhere we have to summon the energy to either fight the cuts or take on the duties just relinquished—be they therapy services, respite, provision of necessary equipment or whatever. This has to come from members of the community who are already severely disadvantaged.

There is a severe problem with disability services and the way they are operated at the moment in our community at both the federal and the state levels. I call upon governments to readdress this issue. The Archbishop of Perth, Barry Hickey, said:

Each of us must make a personal commitment, and a commitment as part of the community, to ensure that everything possible is done so that people with disabilities and their families have the same opportunities for a full life of dignity, joy and belonging.
Reverend Wes Hartley, General Secretary for the Conference of Churches, said:

All people have the right, and indeed the privilege, to a full and complete life. The value of that life and the equal rights of everyone (from the seemingly least powerful to the most powerful) can never be underestimated.

Given that equal value and the equal right to claim on the resources of the community, it is a matter of concern to see so much of the community's resources wasted on trivia and so little expended on essentials.
Ross McLean, the former member for Perth, now the Director of Policy and Parliamentary Liaison with the Chamber of Commerce, said recently:

I continue to be amazed that—in a civilised nation with strong Christian and other religious traditions of tolerance and compassion, in a country enjoying high living standards, having an educated population and with well-developed policies and programs . . . I am amazed that in a nation with all this, it has taken so long for the opinion shakers and policy makers to provide the leadership needed to provide a more enlightened community response to the needs of people with disabilities.

There is a serious problem with the way we fund or go about funding disability services in Australia. I think this issue will come to a head shortly. The time to care program is about to start a program—in fact, it was released last Thursday—called `adopt a politician'. Politicians from all over Australia will shortly be approached by families with disabled children to adopt that politician to show them what it is like to have a severely disabled child in their family.

And I have news for my colleagues, both federal and state: this might be a brand new awakening to some of us because we need to address the really important issues of the community. There is a cry for help—a cry for help from disability services, from these families who really need the opinion makers and the community leaders to stand up for them because these people are there every moment of every day trying to fight this battle. They do not have time to go to public meetings. I went to a public meeting last Thursday which was not very well represented because most of the people were at home looking after their disabled child.

What we need in this issue is compassion and care and a bit of humanity—not the bean counters, not those people who say, `No, let's cut it back right here,' those people who have always been in the Public Service no matter which government was in, whether it be Labor or Liberal. We need some people with compassion and a bit of humanity when it comes to disability services.

I personally think that we should establish some sort of disability trust. At the same time I think when it comes to budget time every year we should address the need for disability services in Australia. We should work out how much they need—at the moment it is about $250 million—and give them that much. That should be the first cheque we pay out. We should draw the line and then see how many ships we need, how many other expenses we have. This is one area that we really need support for and help with.
In conclusion, let me quote a song called `Cry for help'—I will not quote the whole song; I will read out just some of it—which gives a fairly strong message:
Cry for help, please help a mother cries
Give him what he's able to make meaning of his life.
Lifetime rushes by her
Tomorrow's dreams denied her
A child in need required her to forsake the life that was her own.
Who will care for my loved son
When my life is done?

talk.start.para: —I rise in this grievance debate to convey to this parliament the opposition of the residents of western Sydney to the construction of an airport at Badgerys Creek. In doing so, I congratulate the people of western Sydney on their attendance at an anti-Badgerys Creek protest rally at Jamison Park, Penrith on Sunday, 15 March.

speech.para: I would also like to congratulate the Western Sydney Alliance of Mayors, who are in Parliament House today. As I speak they are speaking to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Vaile) and will present him with the document entitled A review of the draft EIS: Second Sydney airport proposal. These mayors are from the councils of Blacktown, Baulkham Hills, Blue Mountains, Campbelltown, Camden, Fairfield, Holroyd, Penrith, Parramatta and Wollondilly.

The attendance of these 15,000 people at this rally at Jamison Park on a wet Sunday afternoon sent a clear message to Canberra that people in western Sydney do not want an airport at Badgerys Creek. An ALP regional assembly held at Blacktown yesterday—attended by federal members from Greenway, Prospect, Chifley and Reid; endorsed ALP candidates from Parramatta, Macarthur, Macquarie and Lindsay; and the Mayor of Blacktown, Charles Lowles—sent the same clear anti-airport message to Canberra.

Many of the general public are critical of politicians because we appear not to be able to reach agreement on major issues, but in opposition to an airport at Badgerys Creek there is a degree of bipartisan support. I noticed at the Jamison Park rally members from both sides of this parliament, as well as state ALP members, Faye Lo Po, John Aquilina, Jim Anderson and Kim Yeadon.

This is a clear statement that these members are prepared to stand up for residents of western Sydney and publicly oppose the airport. There is some irritation among some residents of western Sydney about the delay in making a final decision on Badgerys Creek. People see the government's decision to delay making a decision until after the next election as delaying the obvious and an unnecessary interruption to their lives. This point was clearly made by the alliance this morning at their press conference, where a member of the alliance said quite clearly that they are demanding a decision on Badgerys Creek by this government before the next election. I put it quite clearly that this is a major demand of those mayors in attendance in this parliament this evening.

Most residents of western Sydney now believe that building an airport at Badgerys Creek is a 1980s solution to a year 2010 problem. The solution was based on 1960s and 1970s thinking and research. The western Sydney residential area has expanded and has become more dense, and is now a lot closer to the Badgerys Creek site than it was in 1985.

Since 1985, residents of western Sydney have become more aware of our existing air and water pollution problems, and things would only deteriorate further if an airport were built in western Sydney. Western Sydney residents would agree with Joe Hockey, the Liberal member for North Sydney and chairman of the federal government's community consultative committee on airport noise, who is quoted as saying that Badgerys Creek was unsuitable for an airport because it was landlocked.

Paul Zammit, the new independent member for Lowe is also reported as saying that Badgerys Creek is an unsuitable site. With Badgerys Creek we have a 360-degree problem. No matter which plan we go for, A, B, or C, planes will be flying over residential areas soon after take-off and therefore the residents of Parramatta, Macquarie, Macarthur, Lindsay, Chifley and Greenway will all be affected by aircraft noise and pollution.

The people in the inner city have been complaining for years about increased noise and air pollution and only now are they being listened to. These people are able to get some minimal relief from sea breezes that can move air pollution. Unfortunately it moves westward, but at least they can get some partial, but not permanent, relief.

The children of the inner city are bombarded all day and part of the night by aircraft noise. This stupid proposal for an airport at Badgerys Creek is to bombard 300 schools all day and all residents all night, with no curfew. In spite of this, there is a significant body of opinion, it appears, in Canberra that still wants to build an airport at Badgerys Creek.

The federal transport minister is still saying that the government's preferred option for Sydney's second airport is Badgerys Creek. The Jamison Park Rally was designed to change the views of these pro-Badgerys Creek politicians, none of whom live in western Sydney. Kay Vella put the issue in its correct perspective when she said:
The ALP's overflow airport proposal for Badgerys Creek is long gone.

We are now considering new options, A, B, and C for a major international airport, with aircraft movements up to 360,000 a year and 30 million passengers—and this is the Liberal government's proposal, not Labor's proposal.

I would now like to address the exaggerated claims about employment growth in western Sydney as the result of the new airport. The facts are that companies which win contracts for the construction of an airport at Badgerys Creek would be companies that are already operating in the field. So you would see workers and companies involved, for example, in the Olympic Games facilities, moving to Badgerys Creek. Few new jobs would be created.

If airline companies did move to a new airport at Badgerys Creek, they would take some existing staff with them but, with outsourcing and technological change, employment in the direct airline industry is likely to reduce. Again, few new jobs would be created. Private economic activity does not expand close to an international airport. Ask the small business people of Sydenham, Leichhardt, Summer Hill and Petersham. What happens is that the commercial activity of an airport sucks up small business like a giant vacuum cleaner and the commercial activities of the region come under the control of multinational operators of the airport. Again, there is little new additional employment growth. This is a very important point I want to make. Whatever employment at airports is created, it is not reserved for people who live under flight paths; it is shared by everybody—whatever additional job growth there is.

If I can move on to the EIS report, which we believe is flawed, technically, professionally and morally: one issue not seriously addressed by the EIS was the problem of two airports operating in the Sydney basin. Where would the boundary be when planes leaving Mascot meet planes leaving Badgerys Creek? What safety problems does this create? Did the EIS look at this issue? It did so only briefly, and without real comment. Why? Because it could not afford to buy the necessary information that would have enabled it to research this issue.

The proposed role of the second airport should surely be first premeditated in a proposal and be fully agreed to. Can anybody show any evidence of any airline company that has indicated its willingness to move its operations to Badgerys Creek? In my view, it would take legislation in this House to force airlines to move their operations to Badgerys Creek. What is needed in this whole air transport matter is a bit of sensible but imaginative decision making that is not made with heads in the sand. There is absolutely no argument that can be sensibly raised opposing the building of a second airport at Goulburn tied to the fast train project.

What people would do is simply board the train at Sydney Central, or perhaps Strathfield, and all their customs and other work would be completed on the train. On arrival at Goulburn they would simply join their aircraft and take off, with no further delays. Please do not tell me that a speedy embarkation process is not possible, as measures are already being prepared to speed up disembarkation of passengers during the Olympic Games in Sydney in a couple of years time. The technology is in place, the skills are available and the equipment is available. What is lacking is a clear and intelligent policy that will provide the very best airports and facilities at acceptable sites that meet all environmental concerns of the area.

Remember that international travellers are asked to be at an airport two hours before departure. Many are looking at one or two hours drive to the airport. With better time management, this time could be usefully used travelling to Goulburn with the departure procedures being carried out on the airport train. With the creation of additional jobs being of major importance, the Goulburn option would create far more employment opportunities than building another airport in the Sydney basin.

I conclude by, once again, referring to the alliance's submission, which is being presented to the minister today, and giving good reasons we are opposing the airport at Badgerys Creek: airport noise will ruin the lives of 1.6 million people; air pollution from Badgerys Creek airport and increased road traffic will increase asthma rates in western Sydney by as much as 50 per cent; and Badgerys Creek will ruin the education opportunities of 170,000 children. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise today, in a period of great turmoil for the Gulf of Carpentaria and the little towns there. My grandad went up to Normanton in 1890, and my great-grandad sold up his shop in Brisbane and consolidated in Normanton and Charters Towers—which provides a great deal of mirth for everybody as to his commercial acumen. But, in fairness to the decision of my great-grandaddy, the AMP Society and the four main offices of the Bank of New South Wales were in the three major capital cities, Brisbane, Sydney and Melbourne—and Normanton. The reason for that, as even the most cursory glance at the map of Australia indicates, is that the most central port for all of the Australian land mass is Normanton.

speech.para: Without going into the political reasons—but I think that Mr de Tocqueville had a lot to say about it in his book on democracy in the United States when he talked about the `tyranny of the majority'—Australian government decision making is done by the big cities to suit the big cities; those people who are not fortunate enough to live in the big cities are left out and left behind. That is the basic explanation for the situation.

I went up to these two communities—which are about 60 or 70 kilometres from the sea—and both of those towns were on the sea. The television footage that we took from our aircraft would indicate clearly that they had both become ports, even though they are not ports and are 60 to 70 kilometres from the sea. It was very scary at Karumba—an island, 60 or 70 kilometres from any land—because the people at Karumba had no all-weather airstrip and the airstrip was only in and out for a period of nearly two weeks with the cyclone and the subsequent flooding.

The telephones were out all over the place. Even the town of Croydon went without telephones for a very protracted period, which is not new to us. Julia Creek recently went without telephones for 24 hours. That is because an area the size of Victoria—with 4,000 people there too, I might add—is serviced by a single Telstra technician. The corporatisation introduced by the Labor Party and the subsequent sell-off of part of Telstra has left us without services. You can talk about your community service obligations until the cows come home, but they are not being enforced now and they will most certainly not be enforced in the future.

So we had the situation where we simply had to go without telephones. It was a matter of life and death. There were three men on horses in town when we were there, including Mick Gallagher and his son Ashley. They said that they were looking for cattle. Five hundred head had been on an island. Their telephone was not working. They tried to ring up to get a helicopter to come out to move the cattle off the island because they had no way of getting onto the island, but they could see it and see where the cattle were. A helicopter could have forced the cattle off the island, to swim across to where they could be rescued. But all 500 head of cattle were lost to them, at a value of about $300 to $500 a head. That would have been repeated many times over throughout that area. It was just lucky that they were cattle. It could well have been a station property that was going under water and, because there was no technician to repair the telephones and because the system that was put in by Telstra is very deficient in times of protracted rainfall, it could have been people being threatened by very real danger to their own lives, the lives of their children and their families.

The port there needs to be dredged down to another eight metres, arguably, from where it is at the present moment. The state government has had to put all of the money in there. I am only too well aware of that because I was Minister for Northern Development. I was able to get the slipway electrified, get commercial electrification on in Karumba, build the roads in there, and supply the water there as well. But every single one of those things was done with state government money. That little port, with Century Zinc and the prawning industry worth probably between $100 to $250 million, depending upon what the season is like; and with the live cattle exports of many tens of millions of dollars going through it—we hope this year $100 million going through it—has nearly $1,000 million of earnings for this county flowing through it. What have they got at the present moment? They have a very intermittent airstrip, a very intermittent telephone service and no road access whatsoever. They are cut off for two and three months at a time with no road access. Yet there are some 3,000 or 4,000 people living in this corner of Australia. How can it possibly develop, bereft of all infrastructure and without the services that it once had?

The constitution of Australia is very clear-cut. Aviation is a head of power that belongs to the federal government: it does not belong to local government; it does not belong to state government. Here is a place with $1,000 million worth of produce coming out of its hinterland. Without that port that produce would not be existing for the economy of Australia. Yet it is bereft of all of these things. We are asking the state government continually to put their hands in their pocket for infrastructure items exclusively. The net result of that is that there is no development taking place.

I listened to the Tony Delroy program on the ABC very late—1 o'clock or 2 o'clock in the morning—when I was driving back from Mareeba the other night. Speaker after speaker came on and said, `We couldn't have any more population in Australia because we haven't got any water in this country and because we haven't really got any decent land in this country.' That is the philosophy of Australians over recent years, and that philosophy has been led by the people in this House, I have to say.

You can get in an aeroplane in Townsville and you can fly, as I have on many occasions, all the way across to Western Australia to, say, Broome, and for nearly 10,000 kilometres you will see no sign of human habitation out of either side of that aircraft. No-one is living there. This country is not occupied. That night, for nearly two hours, speaker after speaker rang in and said, `We have no water. We have no decent soils.'

You have just flown over three-quarters of Australia's water and you have just flown over two-thirds of the nation's vertisol soils. There are 21 soil types—if my memory serves me correctly—and the top premium soil type is vertisol soil. Just along the Flinders River alone, there are 15 million hectares of beautiful, flat, rich, rolling, treeless black soil plains. How many farms do we have in North Queensland? I will not take the whole of that area. One-third of Australia's entire water supply is in North Queensland, west of the coastal ranges. I am not talking about where my office is at Innisfail where it never stops raining; I am not talking about the coastal streams—I am talking about the inland streams that run into the Gulf of Carpentaria.

Of the five major rivers in Australia, by volume of water, four are in that area. The Murray-Darling is the biggest river system in Australia. The second biggest is the Mitchell, the third is the Starcke, the fourth is the Normanby and the fifth is the Burdekin. Four of those five rivers are up there in North Queensland. They have 10 times the amount of water of the Murray-Darling system and much more vertisol prime farm soils, and the Murray-Darling produces half of Australia's agricultural production. In all of that vast area of great wealth we have six farms.

A quarter of the world's population will go to bed hungry tonight. I put this to the House: how long is the rest of the world going to accept the situation where we sit on those resources and do nothing with them? The world community will not accept the sort of morality that says that we are entitled to sit on those great resources—those great talents, in the biblical sense—that God has given us and do nothing with them. According to the Queensland government, if we were to invest a lousy $60 million or $70 million in the Hells Gate dam project, that will bring $720 million a year to this nation. (Time expired)

debateinfo.title: PRIMARY INDUSTRIES AND ENERGY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1997

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 10 March, on motion by Mr Truss:
That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —In summing up the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1997 , I want to thank honourable members for their contributions. I want to cover briefly two issues that have been raised during the debate. The bill amends a number of acts to remove the legislative requirement for the portfolio minister to approve the terms and conditions of employment, including remuneration of the principal employee of statutory authorities within the primary industries and energy portfolio, placing the responsibility for this process entirely with the individual portfolio organisations.

speech.para: In no other portfolio has the minister undertaken such a significant role in providing written approval to the terms and conditions of employment of a CEO. The proposed amendments are also consistent with recent developments in the government's approach to public sector workplace relations which indicate that it would be unrealistic to isolate statutory authorities within the primary industries and energy portfolio for ministerial approval of employment conditions—totally inappropriate. Ministerial involvement also necessitates administrative procedures which can be time consuming and which add to the risk of losing prominent appointees due to delays in finalising appointments.

I now turn to the $3.6 million reduction in the Fisheries Research and Development Corporation's special appropriation for 1997-98. We have to make these savings because of the Labor Party's incompetence whilst they were in government. The saving will contribute to our goal of winding back Labor's $10.3 billion budget deficit. The saving will also help pay for the South East Fishery's adjustment program, which we had to set up due to the Labor Party's hopelessly inept management of that fishery. The saving is possible because the FRDC has substantial financial reserves. FRDC will still be able to meet all of its obligations. The reduction will not affect its long-term research priorities. The federal government funds FRDC in a slightly different way to its other primary industries research and development corporations. We make a very large unmatched contribution to the corporation in addition to matching contributions from the fishing industry.

The amendments will only affect our unmatched contribution to FRDC. The government is continuing to match industry contributions on a dollar for dollar basis. The federal government remains committed to research for the fishing industry, and we are demonstrating that by matching the industry's contribution on the basis that for every dollar that they put in, the federal government will put one dollar in for research.

I agree that fisheries research is important, but it was more urgent and important to fix up the south-east fisheries which were so disastrously mismanaged by the previous government. I commend the bill to this House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

I do not want to take too much more time to canvass the points behind the amendments that I have proposed, because I feel that I did that quite adequately in the main contribution I made during the second reading debate on the bill. I feel that the comments made by the minister at the table, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott), a few moments ago would add little to the debate and certainly contain nothing that provided any comfort for those who share my point of view.

To reiterate what these amendments are about, all bar one of them simply remove from the bill those sections which enable the minister to delegate power over senior appointments in the statutory authorities within the portfolio and to take no further role in the appointment of those people in future. As I said in my earlier contribution, we believe that there should be ministerial oversight of these appointments, so we are opposed to the attempt in this bill to remove from ministerial oversight the appointment of the senior personnel in the statutory authorities.

The most significant component of these amendments is the proposal in the bill to allow the government to take $3.6 million out of the reserves of the FRDC to fund, in part, the extra work in the south-east fisheries—the structural adjustment. As I said the other day, if it were any other commodity area where there was a proposal to take funds from the reserves of the research and development corporation and use those funds to finance restructuring taking place elsewhere in the industry—if it were wool, wheat or meat—the members on the other side would be out of their tree. A number of them represent con stituencies where fisheries are a significant component, and I cannot understand why they are standing by and watching the research and development funds being pilfered for this purpose rather than being properly funded off budget, which they should be. This amendment seeks to delete that section of the bill which enables the government to raid the reserves of the FRDC.

I will be persisting with those views; we hold them strongly. I have moved those amendments which will mean that the minister will retain ministerial oversight over the appointments of senior personnel in the authorities, and the other amendment will mean that the $3.6 million stays within the budget of the FRDC and the government will have to look elsewhere for its funds to carry out the completion of the structural adjustment taking place in the south-east fisheries.

talk.start.para: —The government does not support the amendments. As I explained to the House in summing up, as far as research for the fisheries industry—which the member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe) and the opposition are concerned about—is concerned, we are going to be maintaining our dollar for dollar contribution to research in the fishing industry, so it is not as though we are against agricultural research for the beef, wool or fishing industries.
—But you aren't going to contribute.
—We are going to contribute one dollar for every dollar contributed by the fishing industry. The government will not be supporting the amendments.

—I did not want to carry on the debate again tonight but, for the benefit of the minister at the table, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott), I think that you have missed the point. The point is as I made in my contribution the other night. A number of the organisations, including state governments and fishery industry participants—who contribute on a voluntary basis to the research and development funds—have signalled, now that they are aware that the government is up to this stunt of pilfering from the reserves, that they may not in future make their contributions. So it is a bit of a Clayton's offer to stand up here and say, `We will continue to match dollar for dollar the contributions from the industry,' when the industry is saying to you, `Because you are pinching the funds, we are not going to contribute any more.' Of course, if they do not contribute any more, you will not have anything to match, and that is the whole point. So I hope that you can take away a better understanding of this and maybe even bring yourself to ask the minister to reconsider the position—call a quorum or something while you think about it—because I am sure that everyone would welcome a rethink of this on the government side.

speech.para: Question put:
That the amendments (Mr O'Keefe's ) be agreed to.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the negative.

talk.start.para: —In the course of the second reading debate, I raised a range of questions with respect to clauses 40 and 41 of the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1997 which affect the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act. I took the opportunity of forwarding those questions to the relevant minister and asked that the minister at the table be in a position to respond to those questions in the course of the consideration in detail stage of this bill.

speech.para: Those questions which relate to clauses 40 and 41 and affect the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act were, in short, whether the High Court decision in the Commonwealth of Australia v. WMC Resources affects this legislation in any way, whether the Commonwealth has put its mind to that and whether that decision has any implications for this particular bill. I note that in respect of that decision the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Parer) released a statement on 5 February 1998 saying that security of title was essential for offshore leases. Given that this legislation would have been prepared in advance of that High Court decision, my question was whether the government has put its mind to the implications, if any.

Secondly, in respect of petroleum exploration area AC97-1, I inquired whether the required six-month notice to the nation state of Indonesia had been given in accordance with the treaty provisions. I inquired as to when that had occurred and, if that had not occurred, why not. I next raised a question as to the combined effect of article 248 and article 249, given that, under the delimitation treaty, the UNCLOS treaty—the law of the sea—applies. Articles 248 and 249 of the treaty have the effect that research which is conducted is required to be handed over to the relevant nation state. My question of the government here was the extent to which, if at all, research activity which is carried out in the offshore exploration industry is required to be handed over to the state of Indonesia in accordance with the UNCLOS treaty.

This treaty was referred to the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties. In the course of submissions and public hearings on 2 September 1997 and 28 October 1997, it was asserted by officers for the Attorney-General's Department and/or the Department of Primary Industries and Energy that there was a complete answer to that question. That was asserted, but the complete answer to that question was not actually particularised or detailed. In short, that question—which is listed on page 22 of the report—is:

. . . with respect to marine research, whether Australia has a duty to provide Indonesia all of the information detailed at UNCLOS Article 248 and 249(1)(b) and, importantly, to comply with any or all of the other conditions stipulated at Article 249.
