They are some of the key technical amendments that were recommended in the 1996 report that have been included in this bill and, as I said, I will limit my comments to those particular ones, but other recommendations from the 1993 report and from the report on the redistribution have been included. All of the recommendations make for a far better Electoral Act. The integrity of the electoral system has to be kept at an absolute optimum, and the amendments that are proposed within this bill do that. I support it very strongly.

talk.start.para: —I just want to make a few passing comments in regard to this non-controversial piece of legislation, the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill 1997. Our society is constantly changing and to meet the needs of this ever-changing society the function and role of bureaucracies and organisations—government and non-government—need to be constantly reviewed and revised.

speech.para: In 1994 the former Australian Electoral Office was superseded by the Australian Electoral Commission, its role being to provide the Australian people with an independent electoral service which not only meets the needs of the people but also encourages them to understand and participate in the electoral process—in other words, to be an active and participatory member of our democratic society. As with other facets of our democratic society, the AEC has had to move with the times. Over the past two decades a number of reviews have been undertaken by the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters and a number of amendments based on committee recommendations have already been introduced.

The Electoral and Referendum Bill 1997 includes further amendments arising from the recommendations of two Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters reports: on electoral redistribution, tabled in December 1995, and on the conduct of the 1996 federal election, tabled in June 1997. As I said earlier, I would like to comment briefly on three of the proposed amendments. The first concerns recommendation 52 of the 1997 report, which advocates that section 91 of the Electoral Act be amended so that greater detail on individual persons on the electoral roll—that is, their age, gender and salutation—could be made available to senators, members and registered political parties. It was also recommended that this same data could be made available for use in approved medical research and public health screening surveys.

Whilst I would be among the first to admit that gender details, in particular, would make my job as a federal politician much easier when sending out letters to new electors in my area, I am, nonetheless, concerned over privacy issues. What we do not want in Australia is a move towards an Orwellian-type society and, I am afraid to say, we are heading in that direction more and more as time goes on with the greater use of technology.

Proposed section 94A would allow people who are working overseas for a period of less than six years and who would ordinarily be eligible to be on the electoral roll to enrol whilst residing overseas. In today's world, work commitments can often mean that Australians are overseas for extended periods of time but at the same time many, of course, want their vote to count at election time.

The third amendment I want to speak to is the repeal of subsection 329(3) of the principal act. This particular section of the act received considerable media coverage at the last federal election, when Albert Langer advocated a vote other than the full preferential system of voting provided for in section 240 of the principal act, and he was subsequently gaoled for contempt of court.

The result of this amendment is that optional preferential voting will still be valid and people will now be able to lobby others to vote in a similar fashion. It is perhaps an interesting note on our democratic participation in Australia and the very nature of our democratic society when the actions of one person can ultimately lead to a change in electoral legislation. This is not a very controversial bill, so I have restricted my comments to just three amendments. I very strongly support the amendments.

talk.start.para: —Australia's first federal election was held in March 1901. In fact, it was really six separate elections held at more or less the same time and conducted under the widely diverse laws governing lower house elections in each of the states. Some states granted universal franchise; other states restricted eligibility for voters on the grounds of race, sex and property ownership. Some states adopted statewide voting for the House of Representatives; others opted for single member constituencies. In fact, voluntary voting was one of the few features common across the nation, but it did not survive very long. It was decided eventually that compulsory voting would be adopted, which is the system that has served the Australian democracy very well since.

speech.para: Voting systems and determinants of voter eligibility were standardised in the Commonwealth electoral and franchise acts of 1902. In 1918 preferential voting was established. Enrolment was made compulsory in 1911, and voting was made compulsory in 1924, following low turnouts that averaged around 64 per cent. I note that since 1925 turnout has never fallen below 90 per cent. There has been a series of changes since then. The system of electing the Senate was changed in 1948 to proportional representation. In 1973 the voting age was reduced from 21 to 18. Also witnessed in 1983 was a further raft of changes, including above-the-line voting for the Senate.

The important thing is that the result of this evolutionary process is an electoral system which is exceptional in terms of its inclusiveness, its integrity and its fairness. It has to be admitted that this does not mean that the system is perfect. The bottom line is that, while there is always room for reform and improvement, these are not insignificant achievements and they should not be overlooked.

Through the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, the parliament provides a mechanism for considering and recommending reforms and improvements. The bill before the House today is the result of the committee's inquiries. From these have flowed a number of significant recommendations for change to Australia's electoral laws, some of which, including the recommendation for compulsory voting, would fundamentally alter Australia's electoral system. This bill, however, deals essentially with only the technical and comparatively less controversial issues raised in the committee's report. Notwithstanding this, the bill covers a broad range of issues and raises some important questions. I will deal with only four or five of these.

The first relates to redistributions. The redistribution provision in the bill will implement three major changes in the redistribution process. The first is that the initial stage of the process—the determination of state and territory entitlements to House of Representatives seats—will fall due in the 13th rather than the 10th month after the meeting of the newly elected House of Representatives. The rationale for this change is comparatively straightforward. Since entitlements are determined on the basis of current rather than projected population figures, the delay of three months means that the figures used to determine the number of seats to which each state and territory is entitled to at an election will be one calendar quarter closer to the eventual election date. The Australian Electoral Commission has advised that moving the determination to the 13th month should not unduly affect the redistribution timetable or, just as importantly in some senses, subsequent political timetables. This appears to be a logical and workable improvement.

The second change in the redistribution process proposed by the bill relates to the allowable variation between the enrolment numbers in any given division and the statewide average. The bill proposes to extend the degree of tolerance between divisional enrolments and the statewide average to 3.5 per cent 3½ years after the redistribution so as to give greater flexibility to redistribution committees to apply the qualitative criteria while maintaining the primacy of numerical considerations.

The third major change to the redistribution process proposed by the bill relates to the consideration given by redistribution committees to the various qualitative criteria. Currently under section 66(3) of the Commonwealth Electoral Act, the redistribution committee must give due consideration to the division's community of interests, the means of communication and travel, physical features and existing boundaries. The bill proposes that existing electoral boundaries be made subordinate to other qualitative criteria.

I am unsure that this constitutes a major advance in electoral legislation. Existing boundaries are only one of the four criteria. The fact is that, in so far as past redistributions have been valid and well based, the existing boundaries are the sum of the redistribution committee's taking into account community of interests, means of communication and travel, physical features and area.

Axiomatically, existing boundaries should be disturbed as little as possible other than to meet the numerical imperatives or to address past debatable decisions made by the committees. Of course, these are always few and far between. It also needs to be said that the various establishments of boundaries create new communities of interest as groups within the electorate organise themselves in accordance with the confines of their single member constituency.

As I began by saying, I am not sure what this amendment contributes and I do wish to emphasise that redistribution committees would be wrong to see in this amendment a rationale for writing down too far the significance of existing boundaries, either as criteria themselves or as a component of the critical definition of community of interests.

The bill also proposes a couple of sensitive changes to the procedures for candidates nominating for House of Representatives and Senate elections. The nomination deposit will increase from $250 to $350 in the House of Representatives and by an analogous sum in the Senate. Although this is the first increase in 15 years and is significantly less in percentage terms than inflation over the period, there is still a sense in which financial impost is being placed on the exercise of democratic rights. The change will, however, make some of those with no real chance of being elected think more carefully about nominating, and I think this is an important consideration.

In a similar vein is the proposal to increase the number of signatures required in support of the nomination of a candidate not endorsed by a registered political party, from six to 50. I would note in passing, however, that, while the increase in nomination deposits was less than the inflation rate, the increase in signatures required is just a tiny bit in excess of population growth.

The bill also contains a large number of provisions regulating activities during an election campaign and the conduct of the election itself. Most of these are essentially small procedural amendments, but there are a couple of more important and high profile changes responding to the issues raised during the 1996 election by the imprisonment of Mr Albert Langer. This has been canvassed by other speakers in this debate, and I think canvassed very effectively. I believe the bill does address the issues raised by the Langer case.

The consequence of the changes, however, is that a not insignificant number of voters will have their votes ruled invalid as a result of honest mistakes made in filling out the ballot papers. The effective disenfranchisement of voters, no matter what the rationale, is something which needs to be very carefully monitored, and I believe that the commission intends to do that, but I would like to see the results of that monitoring in due course.

The bill introduces a number of changes to Australia's electoral legislation, but it is important that these changes be kept in perspective. They are not made to repair a system which is full of holes, but rather they are designed to improve a system which is amongst the very best in the world in terms of its fairness, its inclusiveness and its integrity. They are part of an ongoing process of evaluation, reform and improvement which goes back to the very early days of Federation, and which will continue so long as we continue to strive to achieve the elusive perfect electoral system.

In this respect I do want to compliment the government for moving on some amendments about postal vote applications which I think are very important and will facilitate the efficacy of voting, particularly on the part of more elderly Australians, who are a very important part of the political system. I commend the government on these amendments.
I believe the fundamentals of the system are right. What is required is finetuning. This bill contributes to that and I commend the bill to the House.

talk.start.para: —Given the hour and the enormous crowd in the gallery, I will keep my comments on the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill 1997 brief. I appreciate the presence of such luminaries as the member for Kooyong (Mr Georgiou), who has an abiding interest in matters of this nature. I see we have another member of the state secretaries club present in the chamber. I will be brief and I will conclude my comments tonight in order to assist the bill going through the House. The bill, as has been said, is essentially a number of minor machinery matters which are a necessary part of the continuing evolution of the system. As the previous speaker said, it is a system we can all be proud of. Just on that point, I am at a loss therefore to understand some of the membership of the current Electoral Matters Committee with respect to their predilection for major changes to the system on the question of voluntary voting. I think that is shared by some members on both sides of the House.
—It is not the subject of this bill.

—It is not the subject of the bill, as I have been reminded. The fact is that we are talking minor amendments here but important ones. The Langer case has been covered by a number of previous speakers, so I will not go into that other than to say that I think what has been proposed will remedy the matter. But we should, as was said earlier, monitor the process in order to see whether it has in fact worked post the next election.

speech.para: A number of changes relate to the question of the redistribution system. As one who has had his seat abolished, I have an enormous grudge against the redistribution system in this country. It is something that has caused me a great deal of pain. I once said that, if you really do not like someone in the political system, the best thing to do is to get them to prepare a redistribution committee submission, because if they are not mad before they start doing it they will be mad after they have completed it. The changes that have been proposed with respect to that I think make sense. Relating to the question of a further quarter's ABS data being available around the matter of whether distributions should in fact be triggered, I think that is sensible. It means that the information that is being utilised in order to make a decision about whether a redistribution is required is more up to date and accurate, and that is to be commended.

On the question of existing boundaries as part of the criteria and making that subordinate to the other criteria such as community of interests, communications, travel and physical features, it is a never-ending battle to understand those criteria in terms of their operation. I can often recall looking at a range of different aspects of a proposed set of maps as produced by a redistribution committee and having had a situation where on different occasions different criteria have been utilised to make a point on the same area. I recall, as I think the member for Kooyong does, the argument on the seat of Flinders in Victoria at the redistribution before last, where it was said it was in effect a silly seat which should not go around Westernport Bay and this redistribution would fix it. The following redistribution reinstigated it. The fact of the matter is that it did not show a lot of rhyme and reason then and it still does not now, so I will look with interest to see how that criterion will in fact operate. I have my doubts as to whether in fact we will see a lot more sense come to the process, but I do think that it is a difficult job and it is not a job that I would wish to have to do myself. I wish the commission all the very best with future redistributions and hope that they will one day shine upon me as they have not done in the past.

talk.start.para: —But you're complaining.
—I have survived, I guess.
—Have you declared an interest?
—I have an interest in this, yes. But, as to whether I have an abiding interest of the intensity of others that might be mentioned today, that is in fact not the case.

speech.para: The fact is that the legislation, as part of that evolution process, is an important part of developing a system which is one of the best in the world. It is a system which is often pointed to overseas, and officers from this country are often used overseas to assist in electoral processes. It is something we should all be proud of and it is something that we should look forward to in the future. I commend the bill to the House and wish it a very speedy passage as we approach the adjournment debate.

talk.start.para: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I propose the question:

interjection.para: That the House do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —Tonight I want to talk about country doctors. Tasmania is suffering from both the state and federal governments not being able to get their acts together with expenditure on health. The result of this is that services are being closed and nothing is being done to replace those services. This is leaving local people without doctors or medical help for long periods when they were used to 24-hour a day district hospitals.

speech.para: This was the situation recently in St Marys on the east coast of Tasmania when the district hospital closed for good, leaving in its place a nine-to-five medical centre. It had played an important role in the community, particularly with the elderly, and led to locals using the town as their main centre. Now people are concerned that without the hospital not only will the medical services be curtailed but the local economy will suffer. Already shopkeepers have reported a drastic decrease in trade and those that used to do their shopping while visiting the hospital are no longer coming. This is what happens when services are downgraded in the country. People do not have many alternatives and many are being left isolated and forgotten or even have to contemplate moving away. This has already made ghost towns of many communities across Australia.

A report compiled recently by the federal government was presented to the federal government's health committee last week, I understand. It included a submission from the Australian Medical Association and the Rural Doctors Association and has a number of recommendations to improve medical work force recruitment and retention schemes for rural and remote areas.

A section of the submission has recognised the plight of country doctors who have to work unaided 24 hours a day, seven days a week. If they do not have a hospital and medical facilities handy they have no backup at all. There was a recognition of a need for incentives to keep doctors in country regions.

This submission looks at putting a further $250 million and employing an extra 1,000 doctors Australia wide by 2003 towards getting on top of the shortage of rural services. There were also calls for national medical recruitment for rural and remote areas and an urgent evaluation of the health infrastructure. There were some very sensible suggestions in the AMA's paper and the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) should give careful consideration to them. Like all other country services, they cannot be expected to operate in a market situation—there has to be input from government. Doctors are no different. Threats to Medicare are certainly not going to help the situation.

I have been in contact constantly with the research going on in rural health and the means by which medical services can be encouraged in rural and remote areas. I think this submission has some worthwhile recommendations. This government should be pursuing them. With the latest debacle at the Premiers Conference, where there was no ability to negotiate better funding for the states' health, only increases the problems for country health generally.

All this nonsense about the repayment of the black hole debt only shows that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and the Treasurer (Mr Costello) do not care about ordinary Australians. If we have a surplus of $2.5 billion in 1998-99, why can't some of it be used to help shore up the medical systems of Australia. Why can't it help some of my electors get into elective surgery? Why can't we?

That $250 million suggested in the submission would make a huge difference to people's lives in the country and it would also give young people from the country areas incentives to train and return to their own districts to practice. It would provide a multiplier effect to country areas and help boost rural economies. I will be interested to see the whole report and see what the profession plans for the future. The government should be releasing it publicly so the community can make its own comments. We need to know what commitment there is to rural and regional people. This government keeps telling us how committed they are. Let us see some evidence of this. This report could be a start. It should be tabled.

talk.start.para: —On Friday 27 February, it was my pleasure to represent the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, the Hon. David Kemp MP, at the Liverpool Regional Museum for the launch of the first work for the dole project that serves my electorate of Hughes. This project was conducted by H&H Accredited Training, whose director, Mr Ray Hill, had the benefit of the positive support of Mrs Christine Raszewski, the curator of the museum, in planning a project that would not only be of significant benefit to the local community but also be of practical value to the young participants.

speech.para: They have succeeded admirably. During the course of my time at the Liverpool Regional Museum, I was impressed by the care and interest shown by the director and the curator towards the young volunteers. It was obvious that the young people themselves were enthusiastic, eager and excited about being involved in this project and that they had a great deal of respect and regard for the organisers. One thing of which Mr Ray Hill is justly proud is that all 120 of his work for the dole participants were volunteers in the scheme. The willingness and cooperative spirit of the young volunteers I met that day certainly conveyed a contagious enthusiasm and commitment.

The work offered to the volunteers included: historical research; the restoration of Collingwood House, one of Liverpool's significant heritage buildings; the renovation of historical machinery; landscape gardening; and bush regeneration. Also included in the project was the establishment of a coffee shop for the museum, which included the preparation and presentation of food and beverages. After the formalities were observed, I and the other guests, including representatives from the Liverpool Council Library, enjoyed morning tea on the veranda that had been prepared and served by the project participants.

The cottage gardens around the museum's courtyard were a riot of colour and the neat edges and well weeded beds gave proof to recent attention by those volunteers who chose landscape gardening as their part of the project. However, I think the most satisfying moment came that morning from a speech given by one of the young volunteers, 20-year-old Peter Vodogaz of Eagle Vale. I would like to share his personal experience of the work for the dole scheme. He said:

Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. My name is Peter. I am a volunteer for a work for the dole scheme and I am currently doing a research project at the Liverpool Regional Museum. The work for the dole scheme is a good initiative begun by the Federal Government. Its aim has been to give the unemployed a chance to give back to the community and to help the community. In essence, it is a community based project. It is beneficial to the community as it is to the volunteer. I know I get a great sense of satisfaction when I finish a project to the best of my ability.
I have enjoyed the research project so far. Joining the scheme has been worthwhile because I have met new people, acquired new skills and been kept busy doing a job I've always wanted to experience.

In my opinion, the work for the dole scheme is a monumental achievement that benefits all involved, as well as the volunteer. I have gained confidence and acquired new skills that hopefully will enhance my prospects in finding a job.

I attended a job interview on Wednesday and the panel of six people asked me what I had been doing while I was looking for a job. I replied that I was attending a work for the dole scheme at Liverpool . . . I immediately saw an interest that they expressed to find out more about the scheme. Hopefully, that will help me.
The work for the dole project gave me a sense of purpose, relieved my boredom and took my parents off my back. I hope that this scheme expands, because it is a great project that works.
I wish to close my speech in saying thank you to the main sponsors H&H Accredited Training for giving me the opportunity to work on this project and making the scheme possible.

The honesty and freshness of Peter's words this morning also conveyed a sense of personal pride and a growing self-confidence as this young man was finding his place in the adult world. He was a delight to talk to, and he was positive about his future. He was also concerned that other young people should get a similar chance. He said to me that he hopes the government will keep the scheme going for unemployed young people in his area. Not only does it bring new skills; more importantly, it brings self-esteem, confidence and self-respect. It also brings older members of the community to regard more highly and respect these young people.

I am personally grateful that the government has provided for a further 25,000 in the work for the dole scheme in 1998-99. It will then spread the growing sense of self-esteem and confidence for many more young people and allow them to take their place amongst their fellow Australians with pride.

talk.start.para: —I have received a letter from Messrs Deacons Graham and James acting for Mr Ted Baillieu. They have drawn my attention to a question I asked of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) in the House of Representatives on 2 March 1998. In that question I asked:

speech.para: My question is directed to the Prime Minister, and it follows the answer that was previously given. Is the Prime Minister aware that his Minister for the Environment has acknowledged personally intervening in Victorian funding applications, in a supposedly independent funding appraisal process, to reinstate three rejected applications and, in doing so, approved $52,000 for fencing a single rural property? Is the Prime Minister aware that the successful applicant in that case, given $52,000 of taxpayers' money, is actually a private pastoral company owned by the Baillieu family—the family of Ted Baillieu, former president of the Victorian Liberal Party? How can the Prime Minister condone this outrageous case of ministerial intervention which resulted in the reinstatement and funding of a Natural Heritage Trust project for the benefit of the Liberal Party faithful?

Messrs Deacons Graham and James advise that the company in question was and is owned by `Mr Anthony Baillieu, our client's second cousin and his family'. I accept that. Mr Ted Baillieu, by his solicitor, also asks me to accept that he had nothing to do with the property in question or its owner and knew nothing of the application to the trust, and that the grant was made without his influence. I have never suggested otherwise, and I express my regret if Mr Ted Baillieu thought that I did.

All my criticism of the allocation of funding under the Natural Heritage Trust has been directed towards the bias in the way in which the fund has been distributed by the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill) and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson). I have alleged no impropriety on behalf of any applicant. But the opposition, however, has a mountain of evidence of abuse of process regarding the funding grants under the Natural Heritage Trust by these ministers and still has legitimate questions about the way in which the government is prepared to squander taxpayers' money.

No-one should forget that this was a dividend that was intended to come from the sale of Telstra, which every Australian owned and which the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) promised to be an additional investment over and above recurrent budget funding in capital and much needed environmental projects. The community had only one bite at that cherry, and the opposition has an obligation to make the government accountable for every cent of it.

Members might recall that the opposition warned from the beginning that the government was likely to ensure that the Natural Heritage Trust became a Liberal Party slush fund. The proof of the pudding is in the eating. Nine dollars out of every $10 spent by the trust attributable to federal electorates went to coalition seats. The Prime Minister responds with a simplistic explanation and says why would anyone be surprised, as the environmental problems are in rural and regional Australia and the coalition holds most of those seats.

But when looking at the average allocation per seat in rural and regional Australia—in other words, when we compare apples with apples—we still find a massive bias in favour of coalition seats. For example, coalition held regional seats received five times the average allocation for Labor held regional seats. Given that the coalition holds 10 provincial seats and the ALP holds eight, how does Mr Howard seriously expect anyone not to suspect bias?

We also still remain suspicious of a Minister for the Environment who refuses to provide satisfactory answers to legitimate questions. He ducks and weaves and rants, but he will not answer those questions. We still have outstanding FOI requests which have not been responded to. We still do not know why, after the exhaustive so-called expert and independent multi-tiered appraisal and recommendation process, Senator Hill asked Senator Crane, a Liberal senator, to advise him on funding projects in that senator's home state and Mr Billson, the Liberal member for Dunkley, was flown to South Australia to advise Senator Hill on the funding grants for Mr Billson's home state of Victoria. We know that Mr Billson was still boasting about ensuring that a late and out of time application from his own electorate was considered.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. That grotesque assertion from the so-called gentleman at the box is factually incorrect. I ask him to withdraw it.
—That is not a point of order.

—We know that there has been an abuse by funds being removed from what was supposedly capital expenditure for recurrent purposes. We know there has been cost shifting within the fund—ordinary expenditures of government funded out of the Natural Heritage Trust. We know that the process has been corrupted by the way in which the government has abused the fund. (Time expired)

—I want to make some comments with respect to the situation in Asia at this time. I am indebted to Austrade's Mr Michael Crawford for the information I will relate to the House. I want to stress to the House how important it is not to group all of our Asian neighbours into a single category. Asia is made up of many countries, and they are very different—different cultures, different peoples and certainly very different economies. I want to mention Australia's trade position in respect of some of those countries. It is well worth noting, for example, the merchandise exports to East Asian countries over two separate six-month periods, from July 1996 to January 1997 and during the period July 1997 to January 1998—particularly important in respect of a number of our major trading partners. The Australian merchandise exports to some of these countries are very significant during those two periods.

speech.para: In the PRC, for example, total exports during the July 1996-97 period were $1,962 million and in the corresponding period from July 1997 to January 1998 they were $2,365 million, an improvement of 20.5 per cent. There has been a quite remarkable leap in Hong Kong where there has been a massive increase in total exports of Australian merchandise products to Hong Kong—a 48.5 per cent improvement. For Indonesia, about which we are hearing so much of the difficulties that they are having with their currency and their economy, the change over that same corresponding six-month period was 1.6 per cent.

Let us look at our major trading nations. Japan had a massive increase from $8,932 million to $10,525 million—a change of $1,593 million or a 17.8 per cent improvement. Looking down through a whole range of them, the Philippines had a 17.6 per cent improvement, Singapore a 17 per cent improvement, Taiwan a 22.1 per cent improvement and, of the remaining ones, Korea was down 11.5 per cent, Thailand down 9.2 per cent and Malaysia down 0.8 per cent. The overall change, quoting all of those countries—China, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, Korea, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore, Taiwan and Thailand—was an overall 12 per cent improvement in our trade with those countries and the Australian merchandise exports have made a significant thrust forward into those countries.

I want to compliment the fine work being done, particularly by the Minister for Trade, the Hon. Tim Fischer, and his parliamentary secretary, Senator David Brownhill, and also our Austrade officials throughout our neighbouring Asian countries, both in those countries and here in Australia. They are certainly making a major thrust into South-East Asia, particularly those countries I have mentioned. The performance of Australia's trading situation in respect of Australian merchandise exports is very favourable and improving all the while. The major thrust of this government into improving our export relationship with all of those South-East Asian countries is to be commended.

talk.start.para: —I wish to return tonight to something I raised in the House back on 27 February last year, and that is incidents on the Thai-Burmese border. On Wednesday, 11 March a refugee camp with refugees of Karen ethnicity was attacked by Burmese forces. The name of the camp is the Huay Kalok refugee camp. This has special moment for me and also for the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur), who is in the chamber tonight, because back in September 1995 I, as the leader of a parliamentary delegation and the honourable member for Corangamite, as the deputy leader, visited this camp.

speech.para: Regrettably, at the time that I first heard of reports this year, I was unsure that yet again it was this particular camp, but on Saturday, 21 March in the Age there was quite a good article about the incident. In that incident the head of the camp is quoted—and the head of the camp is a rather remarkable woman, Mary O. In the report of the delegation we refer to Mary O, and we had this to say about her:

Wangka camp is headed by Mary O who was a major in the Karen Army. She is a dynamic and impressive person who works tirelessly for the welfare of her people, ensuring the camp is well organised and that there are at least very basic facilities, like schools, a clinic and running water.

This is a refugee camp of bamboo buildings. It is surrounded by rice paddies. At the time of the attack this year, many of the people living in the camp fled into those rice paddies. Unfortunately, there were a number who were injured and now are hospitalised. Last year when I rose to speak about this there had been an earlier attack in January of that year. These people are already living a very hard existence. In our report we made mention that many of the children who lived in those camps had been born into those camps and actually had fulfilled their primary and secondary education in the schools in those camps.

We pay tribute to the way in which the Karen people had organised themselves within the camps and we also pay tribute to the desire that the Karen people have simply to return to Burma to live in peace. We refer to the camp as the Wangka camp only because that is the nearest Burmese village across the border and the people who lived in the camp preferred to refer to it in that way. In the report in the Age Mary O has this to say:
We have to suffer, but our morale has been quite good up to now . . . If there was genuine peace, we would return home tonight, we would not wait until tomorrow.

When the delegation visited the camp, one of the most moving moments of the whole delegation was when Mary O on our departure said, `Come back and visit us in Burma.' I know that it is very difficult to make comment about the way in which another country deals with a situation like this. I am full of praise for the efforts of the Thai officials and the way in which they have cooperated in the running of the camp. There are stories that part of the problem is the trafficking of forestry products from Burma into Thailand and the protection, therefore, of the border—and the involvement perhaps of Thai army officials.

At the time of the incidents last year, the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer) in an answer to a question on 3 March said that he would be asking our officials in Bangkok to speak to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Thailand to confirm that it was not the case that the Thai military was involved in any of the incidents and that it was not the wish of the Thai officials that the Karen people should be repatriated against their will. I hope that the Minister for Foreign Affairs will ensure that there is continuing support of the aid projects that are carried out not only in this particular camp but also in a number of the camps along the Thai-Burmese border by an organisation known as the Burmese Border Consortium and organisations such as Medecins Sans Frontieres.

I believe that one of the ways in which Australia can establish its credibility and establish its credentials within the region is by ensuring that it continues to play an active part in trying to see that these people are able to resume their proper place—that is, living in Burma. I know that the UNHRC are perhaps going to be invited to be involved. I hope that that is the case because that has been one of the stumbling blocks. These people are referred to as displaced people and not as refugees because the UNHRC has not yet any official status. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Tonight I want to speak about a recent development in Australia's stock markets, and that is the situation which has occurred in the last six months where four out of 10 adult Australians now participate in the Australian stock market. Twenty-nine per cent of adults now directly own shares. Only the United States has a higher level of participation. High levels of domestic ownership contribute to two goals that this government has: one, the goal of making Australia the No. 2 financial centre after Tokyo in the Asia-Pacific region and, also, John Howard's stated goal of making Australia one of the great share owning democracies in the world, with more stakeholders in Australian capital than ever before.

speech.para: I do not know how the Labor Party feel about this development. How will they respond to this development? It looks like this is the sort of development which would have Labor marching in the opposite direction. How do they feel about having a nation of mini-capitalists? When you look at where the fastest growth is occurring, it is occurring amongst people aged 25 to 34 on average incomes and in regional areas more than in city areas.

People have often said that the Australian Labor Party and Liberal and National parties are like the Tweedledum and Tweedledee of Australian politics, that there is no real difference between the coalition and the ALP, but on the issue of state ownership of government business enterprises you could not be further from the truth because this is an area that really does still distinguish the Labor Party from the coalition. It was at the 1921 ALP conference that the party objective—the socialisation of industry, production, distribution and exchange—was adopted by Labor. If you look around the world, in Britain Tony Blair removed the socialist clause from British Labour's platform. The ALP is unable or unwilling to do the same. Why won't Kim Beazley remove the socialist clause from the ALP? Do the Labor Party still hold this up as a party objective? Do the Labor Party believe that the principle of state common ownership of Telstra is so important that they will be prepared to renationalise the one-third that was privatised last year? I would like to see that as a Labor Party motion at a future Labor Party conference.

There are few Communist governments left in power around the world. In 1959 when Fidel Castro came to power in Cuba he seized the assets of the ITT Corporation, which operated Cuba's phone system. Thirty-five years later, in 1994, Cuban telecommunications were partially privatised by selling 49 per cent to Italian and Mexican phone companies. In that period, Cuba went from having 400 long distance phone calls per day to 60,000 calls per day. Mr Speaker, you might remember that, at the end of the Cold War when the Gulf War coalition was put together, the Soviet Union, for the first time in that 40 years, agreed with the United States and China did not oppose, and there were still the last remaining isolated, recalcitrant states which opposed the American led coalition attack on Iraq. They were states like North Korea, Cuba, Yemen and Albania.

It is very interesting to see that Albania, one of the most isolated Communist nations in the world, began the road to privatisation in 1995. In South Africa, the ANC government, which contains members of the South African Communist Party, privatised 30 per cent of Telkom—their national carrier—in 1997. So around the world we have this extraordinary situation where the members of the internationale—the international grouping of Communist Party members—are actually less wedded to common state ownership of enterprises than the ALP and the Australian Democrats. On this issue, the ALP and the Australian Democrats are more left wing than Fidel Castro, they are more left wing than the South African Communist Party and they are more left wing than Albania.

By selling the remaining two-thirds of Telstra, we can reduce the interest bill on the debt which Labor left us by $3 billion per year forever. Taking into account the loss of the Telstra dividend, this would provide $1.5 billion to $2 billion each and every year to spend on areas like the environment, health or aged care. Selling Telstra would lead to lower costs and make it more commercial in operation. Of course you need guarantees. You need guarantees on foreign investment—limiting foreign investment to 35 per cent and five per cent for any foreign carrier. Maintaining untimed local and data calls is very important for the Internet. It is also important to maintain price capping for rural users and maintain standard telephone services for all Australians. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —This evening, in the context of the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill 1997 which the House currently has before it, I would like to take the opportunity of paying tribute to a very fine Commonwealth public officer who has recently announced his retirement, and that is Mr Barry Young, who was the Chief Commonwealth Electoral Officer for Western Australia. My contact with Mr Young has been as state secretary of the Western Australian branch of the Australian Labor Party. My contact with him was in the usual way, as reflected by the bill before the House, both as far as elections were concerned and redistributions. Obviously, as the member for Perth I have also had contact with him in the various elections when I have stood as candidate for Perth and for redistributions.

speech.para: Over those years and through the conduct of a number of elections and redistributions, Mr Young has always struck me as being a person of very great integrity, a man of very great decency, professional and impartial—the sort of fine upstanding Commonwealth electoral officer that I think the Commonwealth can pride itself on. His retirement is in part as a result of a recent family tragedy which has seen his family being the subject of great sympathy throughout the state of Western Australia. I take this opportunity on behalf of my Western Australian colleagues of wishing Mr Young all the best for his retirement.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 23 September 1997:

question.para: (1) Does the Australian Bureau of Statistics expect that private sector new capital investment will be 2.4% below the comparable figure in 1996-97; if so, is his Department reviewing its forecasts of economic growth; if not, why not.

(2) Have stock markets in the Asian region recently collapsed; if so, (a) has his Department made recommendations on the likely impact on Australian economic growth and (b) will the impact on currencies have a negative impact on Australian trade in the region.
(3) Has his Department analysed the probable impact the El Nino effect will have on Australian agricultural output over the next 12 to 18 months; if so, what are the details; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The most recent data in respect of private sector investment expectations for 1997-98 were published on 26 February 1998 in Private new capital expenditure and expected expenditure to June 1999 (ABS Catalogue No. 5625.0). Based on responses from businesses to the survey conducted in January and February, estimated private new capital expenditure for 1997-98 is $46,074 million. This, the fifth estimate for the 1997-98 financial year, is 5.6 per cent higher than the estimated level of new capital expenditure reported by businesses in the fifth set of investment expectations for 1996-97.

Investment intentions data are not used in isolation to forecast investment. A broad range of factors are considered, particularly the key influences on investment such as the rate of return on the capital stock, capacity utilisation, profitability, and the cost of borrowing. In addition, leading indicators, such as approvals, commencements and finance commitments, are also examined when preparing investment forecasts.

At present, both the investment fundamentals and leading indicators point to strong growth in real business investment in 1997-98. The outlook for business investment, including revised forecasts for growth in business investment in 1997-98, is discussed in detail in the Government's Mid-year Economic and Fiscal Outlook.

(2) (a) and (b) There has recently been considerable instability in some Asian financial markets, particularly in the ASEAN countries (Thailand, Malaysia, Indonesia and the Philippines) and Korea. This instability and its impact on trade and the outlook for the Australian economy are discussed in detail in the Government's Mid-year Economic and Fiscal Outlook.

(3) Drier than normal weather conditions have occurred throughout much of 1997. However, timely rainfall occurred in September, resulting in upward appraisals of winter crop production to around expectations formed at the commencement of the season. In terms of the outlook, the most recent Bureau of Meteorology reports indicate that slightly drier than normal weather conditions are expected to continue into mid 1998. The implications of weather conditions for farm production were addressed in the Government's Mid-year Economic and Fiscal Outlook.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 18 November 1997:

question.para: (1) Has his attention been drawn to recent comments of the German Ambassador to Australia, Mr Klaus Zeller, that the Government's unwillingness to commit Australia to participation in the Expo 2000 World Trade Fair in Hanover, Germany, is a total contradiction of everything Australia wants to achieve in Germany and Europe; if so, what is his response.

(2) Has his attention also been drawn to recent comments by the Western Australian Government's Agent-General in London, Mr Clive Griffiths, that the federal Government' s unwillingness to commit Australia to participation in Expo 2000 was terrible and very damaging to Australia; if so, what is his response.

(3) Did he have discussions, formal or otherwise, with a representative of the German government regarding Australia's participation in Expo 2000 before the comments referred to in parts (1) and (2) were made; if so, (a) what was the nature of the discussions and (b) did he give any undertakings concerning Australia's participation; if so, what undertakings.
(4) Has he or his representative given an assurance to a representative of the German government that Australia would participate in Expo 2000.

(5) Did he state in the House on 9 May 1996 that the Government would give important priority to relations with Europe during its time in office; if so, how is this consistent with the Government's decision concerning participation in Expo 2000.

(6) Has he made personal representations to (a) the Prime Minister or (b) the Treasurer to seek the funds needed to establish an Australian pavilion at the Expo 2000; if so, what was the outcome; if not, why not.

(7) Would an Australian pavilion at Expo 2000 lead to (a) opportunities for Australian businesses in Australia and abroad, (b) consequent job opportunities for unemployed Australians and (c) the promotion of Australia to tens of millions of expected visitors to Expo 2000; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes. The Government's initial decision not to participate in Expo 2000 was made in the 1996-97 budget context. The Prime Minister announced on 1 December 1997 that the States and Commonwealth would share the costs of Australian participation in Expo 2000
(2) Yes. I refer to my answer in part (1)
(3) Yes.
(a) The discussions were private.

(b) I refer the Honourable Member to the record of my press conference in Dresden on 7 November in which I indicated that the Government would be looking at a variety of funding options with the private sector, the State Governments and the Federal Government.
(4) The Australian Ambassador in Bonn has conveyed the Prime Minister's decision to Chancellor Kohl and Foreign Minister Kinkel.
(5) Yes. Australia's participation in Expo 2000 is consistent with this statement.
(6) Such discussions as took place were private.
(7) Responsibility for Australia's participation in Expo 2000 rests with the Minister for Sport and Tourism.
